options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: Distance is used for speed, while displacement is used for velocity.

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Speed is a vector quantity, while velocity is a scalar quantity.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Speed is used for distance, while velocity is used for displacement.

options.label: D
options.text: Speed is used for scalars, while velocity is used for vectors.

options.label: C

title: Science can answer moral questions - Sam Harris

multiple-choice.question: What is the general understanding of the relationship between science and human values?

options.label: A
options.text: Science can determine what we ought to value.

options.label: B
options.text: Science can help us get what we value but cannot tell us what we ought to value.

options.label: C
options.text: Science and human values are interchangeable terms.

options.label: D
options.text: Science is the only source of human values.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the illusion that most people have regarding science and human values?

options.label: A
options.text: That science can determine what we ought to value.

options.label: B
options.text: That science and human values are separate entities.

options.label: C
options.text: That science is the only source of human values.

options.label: D
options.text: That human values are not important.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's argument regarding values and facts?

options.label: A
options.text: Values and facts are separate entities.

options.label: B
options.text: Values are a certain kind of fact.

options.label: C
options.text: Facts are a certain kind of value.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the crucial thing to notice about values and conscious experience?

options.label: A
options.text: Values are not related to conscious experience.

options.label: B
options.text: Values are only related to human conscious experience.

options.label: C
options.text: Values are related to the conscious experience of all beings.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's argument regarding the concept of well-being?

options.label: A
options.text: The concept of well-being is undefined and vacuous.

options.label: B
options.text: The concept of well-being is defined and objective.

options.label: C
options.text: The concept of well-being is only related to human experience.

options.label: D
options.text: The concept of well-being is not important.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the relationship between morality and facts?

options.label: A
options.text: Morality is not related to facts.

options.label: B
options.text: Morality is only related to human facts.

options.label: C
options.text: Morality is related to facts about the conscious experience of all beings.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's argument regarding the moral landscape?

options.label: A
options.text: The moral landscape is flat and objective.

options.label: B
options.text: The moral landscape is complex and subjective.

options.label: C
options.text: The moral landscape has peaks and valleys that correspond to differences in well-being.

options.label: D
options.text: The moral landscape is not important.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the problem with the current discourse on morality?

options.label: C
options.text: We value differences of opinion too much.

options.label: D
options.text: We do not value differences of opinion enough.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's argument regarding moral expertise?

options.label: B
options.text: Moral expertise is only possible for certain individuals.

options.label: C
options.text: Moral expertise is possible and important.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the goal for the future of human discourse on morality?

options.label: A
options.text: To continue valuing differences of opinion.

options.label: B
options.text: To converge on the answers to moral questions.

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore the concept of well-being.

options.label: D
options.text: To prioritize individual interests over collective well-being.
